book_title: Al-Fawakeh Al-Adhab in response to those who did not rule by the Sunnah and the Book
text: Appreciation by the great scholar Sheikh Saleh bin Ibrahim Al-Bulaihi In the name of Allah, the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful Praise be to Allah, Lord of the Worlds. And I bear witness that there is no god but Allah alone, with no partner. And I bear witness that Muhammad is the servant of Allah and His Messenger. May Allah bless him and grant him peace and his family and companions altogether. As for what follows, it is known that Sheikh Muhammad bin Abdul Wahhab, may Allah have mercy on him, is considered one of the renewers of the religion of Islam. Likewise, his children, grandchildren, and all his students carried out what he did and called for what he called for, namely the monotheism of Allah and singling Him out for worship in all its forms. Among his students is a virtuous scholar well-versed in the arts of knowledge, this scholar is "Hamad bin Nasser bin Uthman Al Muammar", may Allah have mercy on him. This scholar, who is one of the giants of scholars, has sound and wise answers in the famous messages arranged by Sheikh Abdul Rahman bin Qasim, may Allah have mercy on him. And he has a good, beneficial, and useful treatise that a student of knowledge should read and contemplate well because of the beneficial knowledge it contains. He named this treatise "Al-Fawakeh Al-Adhab in response to those who did not rule by the Sunnah and the Book" (The Sweet Fruits in Response to Those Who Did Not Judge by the Sunnah and the Book). The reason for writing the treatise is that Ghalib the Sharif, the Emir of Mecca, sent to Imam Abdul Aziz bin Saud asking him to send him some of the scholars he had to debate the scholars of the Haram. That was in the year 1211 AH, and since this is a great task and has its results and has

text: its consequences, the Imam sent him a scholar knowledgeable and well-versed in the arts of knowledge: especially the science of beliefs and monotheism, who is "Hamad bin Nasser Al Muammar". When Hamad bin Nasser arrived with his companions in Mecca and performed their Umrah, the Sharif gathered the scholars of Mecca, then the debate took place in several sessions. This debate was attended by a large number of the people of Hijaz. And a large crowd: After exchanges, give and take, and heated debates whose sparks flew: and whose smoke rose, after that the flags of victory were fluttering on the side of Sheikh Hamad bin Muammar: where he prevailed over the debaters: with evidence and proof: and argument and clarification: And so it was and so it will be, everyone who is on the side of truth will rise and will be head held high and will be victorious: and will be triumphant over his opponent. In fulfillment of His saying, the Most High: {And it was incumbent upon Us to help the believers}. And among what happened in the debate sessions is that the scholars of Mecca from the Hanafis, Malikis, and Shafi'is asked Hamad bin Nasser about several issues, so he answered them about three issues. He answered them with what heals the sick and quenches the thirst. And removes doubts. And burns fallacies: And he said if you answer these three issues, we will answer you about the rest of the issues: As it was said and is said, seeing is believing. After that, I give way to the dear reader to read the three issues and read their answer: as they were before him. And Allah is the Granter of success and the Guide to the path of righteousness. After what has preceded, I say to the virtuous readers, we all have a brother in Allah. He is Professor Abdul Salam bin Barjas bin Nasser Al Abdul Karim. And in what I believe is that Allah granted him success, he thought about a subject that no one else thought about, and his blessed idea has been realized by action, and here he is, may Allah guide his steps at the beginning of the road

book_title: Al-Fawakeh Al-Adhab in response to those who did not rule by the Sunnah and the Book
text: This idea is finding and bringing out the books and treatises written by the scholars of the Salafi call: namely Sheikh al-Islam Muhammad bin Abdul Wahhab and his students and the students of the students. So Professor Abdul Salam undertook the publishing of these treatises, verifying them, and graduating their hadiths. And numbering the Quranic verses found in them. And that is only because the books and treatises written by these virtuous scholars, most scholars and students of knowledge who studied in institutes, colleges, universities, intermediate and secondary schools, do not know anything about these valuable books. And they are from our precious and valuable heritage. So may Allah reward the virtuous brother Professor Abdul Salam bin Barjas with the best reward and may Allah reward us and him with the reward of the doers of good and reformers and grant us and him sincerity in intention, word, and deed. And the first treatise that brother Abdul Salam verified and graduated its hadiths and brought to existence is "Refuting Doubts on Monotheism" by the huge scholar, the Mufti of the Najdi lands in his time, Abdullah bin Abdul Rahman Aba Butain. And the second treatise that brother Abdul Salam verified is "Question and Answer in the Most Important Matters" by Sheikh Abdul Rahman bin Sa'di. And the third treatise is "Verifying the Speech on the Legitimacy of Aloud Dhikr after Prayer" by the learned scholar Sulaiman bin Sahman. And the fourth treatise which is "Al-Fawakeh Al-Adhab in response to those who did not rule by the Sunnah and the Book" by the scholar Sheikh Ibn Muammar, which is the one before the reader. So may Allah reward brother Abdul Salam on behalf of Islam and Muslims with the best reward and may Allah maximize for us and him the reward and recompense.

text: In the name of Allah, the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful "Investigator's Introduction" Praise be to Allah who sent His messengers as bringers of good tidings and warners, and sent down with them the Books and the Balance, to establish the argument against all the worlds, and to distinguish the party of Allah from the party of devils. I praise Him, Glory be to Him, for the visible and hidden blessings He has bestowed upon us, and for warding off from us the various evils and misfortunes. And I bear witness that there is no god but Allah alone, with no partner, to Him belongs praise in the first and the last. And I bear witness that our Prophet and Master Muhammad, through whom Allah erased the worship of idols, trees, and statues, and removed through him the landmarks of disbelief, immorality, stone altars, and divining arrows, and nullified through him the oppression and crime that the people of ignorance were upon. So Allah raised through him the Hanifiyya, the religion of Abraham, peace and blessings be upon him, after its landmarks had become obliterated, and promised him to preserve and spread it over the years and days. So He supported him with the Quran in which is guidance, clarification, and healing for ailments, and gave him with it the comprehensive speech and words. So may Allah purify and complete peace upon him and his noble, majestic companions, who realized monotheism and established it properly, and struggled for it with all the strength and good argument they were given, and fought those who deviated and turned away from it and directed worship to other than the All-Knowing King until the settled and the bedouin became upright upon it as it should be and desired. So you do not see in their time anyone rushing to the people of the graves in grave calamities, nor anyone fleeing to supplication and intercession by the prophets and righteous people in great disasters, nor

text: anyone building domes, silk, and marble over graves. So may Allah be pleased with them as they preserved the religion of Islam for us, and may Allah be pleased with those who followed them and traced their footsteps until the Day of Resurrection. As for what follows, this is the second treatise from the series of treatises and books of the eminent scholars of Najd, and it is from the writings of the learned scholar Sheikh Hamad bin Nasser Al Muammar - may Allah Almighty have mercy on him - named "Al-Fawakeh Al-Adhab in response to those who did not rule by the Sunnah and the Book". This treatise is unique in its chapter, marvelous in its style and address, refined and revised for its students. It included, despite its small size, the establishment of monotheism, and the refutation of the roots of polytheism and denunciation, and that is with clear evidences from the Glorious Book, and from the authentic Sunnah of the best of creation and servants, peace and blessings be upon him. So it is a treatise worthy of attention, high in rank and status, students should seek help from it, and scholars possessing intellect should not turn away from it.

book_title: Al-Fawakeh Al-Adhab in response to those who did not rule by the Sunnah and the Book
text: The copies relied upon in the verification When I started verifying this book, several copies were available to me: First: A manuscript copy preserved in the Riyadh Saudi Library under number "86/ 613" consisting of twenty-four plates. It is a copy with good handwriting, in which the name of the copyist and the date of copying were not mentioned. But the copyist mentioned what indicates that it was written during the reign of Imam Abdul Aziz bin Muhammad bin Saud, may Allah have mercy on him, in his saying: "... Ghalib, the governor of Noble Mecca, requested from Abdul Aziz bin Muhammad bin Saud, the governor of Najd, may Allah let us enjoy his life..." So based on this, this copy must have been written during the life of the author, may Allah have mercy on him, because Imam Abdul Aziz died in the year "1218 AH" and the author died seven years after him. So this copy was definitely written before the year "1218 AH" and the symbol for this copy is the letter "A". Second: Another manuscript copy also preserved in the Riyadh Saudi Library under number "86/ 607" consisting of twenty-five plates. It is a copy with good handwriting, many spelling errors, written in the handwriting of someone named "Abdullah bin Ahmad" and its copyist did not mention the date of copying. This copy was written after the death of Imam Abdul Aziz bin Muhammad, i.e., after the year "1218" as indicated by the copyist's saying: "... the governor of Najd, may Allah have mercy on him and cover him with His mercy..." and the reference to this copy is with the letter "B".

text: Author's Biography " (*) He is the Imam, the scholar, the erudite, the grand scholar, the sea of understanding, the verifier, the Mujtahid, the Hafiz, the multi-talented, the suppressor of the anthropomorphists, and the raiser of the banner of the monotheists, the venerable Sheikh, the noble meticulous investigator, Hamad bin Nasser bin Uthman bin Hamad bin Abdullah bin Muhammad (**) bin Hamad bin Hasan bin Touq bin Saif Al Muammar (1) Al-Anqari Al-Saadi" (2) Al-Tamimi Al-Najdi Al-Hanbali. And this Hasan bin Touq is the one who migrated from "Tharmada" to "Mulhum" then came to "Al-Uyaynah" and in it were the Al Yazid from Bani Hanifa, so he bought it from them in the year "(850) AH" and settled in it, he and his children. And it continued to grow little by little until it reached the peak - among the towns of Najd - in urban progress and large population
foot_note:
1. (*) Sources of the biography: 
1 -. Rawdat Al-Nazirin about the feats of the scholars of Najd and the events of the years by Al-Qadi. 
2 -. Al-Durar Al-Saniyyah in the Najdi Answers Vol 12 by Sheikh Ibn Qasim. 
3 -. Scholars of Najd during six centuries by Al-Bassam. 
4 -. Unwan Al-Majd by Ibn Bishr. (**) In our tree it occurred "Rajih" instead of "Muhammad". Some of the elders of Al Muammar wrote this lineage to me and affirmed the name "Muhammad" instead of "Rajih" and this is what the historian Hussein bin Hasan affirmed in his book "A'lam Tamim - p. 391". I say perhaps his nickname was "Rajih" and "Muhammad" was his name, and Allah Almighty knows best. 
1. And the writer of this biography meets with the author in the seventh grandfather. 
2. Attributed to Bani Saad bin Zaid Manat bin Tamim.

text: And commercial and scientific movement, especially in the time of the Emir - Abdullah bin Muhammad bin Muammar - as Ibn Bishr said in Unwan Al-Majd. The virtuous Sheikh Abdullah bin Bassam - may Allah protect him - mentioned in his book Scholars of Najd "1/ 239" that between the subject of the biography and Hasan bin Touq there is a kinship of ten grandfathers whose names he could not find. So he said: And the correct is that between him and Hasan there are five grandfathers, and their names are known, and I have established them from our tree "Al Abdul Karim", and from the elders of the "Al Muammar" family. This great scholar was born in the city of "Al-Uyaynah" in the year "1160 AH" and it was at that time the largest city in Najd, just as it is the town of his clan Al Muammar - the rulers of Al-Uyaynah - so he was from a house of rule and emirate. It is known that Al-Uyaynah, after the establishment of the call of Imam Sheikh Muhammad bin Abdul Wahhab, was influenced by his call, and there were people in it who were supporters of his methodology, so the subject grew up in it and took knowledge from its scholars who are followers of Sheikh Muhammad bin Abdul Wahhab. When he grew up, he desired to increase in knowledge, so he traveled to "Diriyah", the headquarters of the call of Sheikh al-Islam. And he adhered to Sheikh al-Islam in it like a shadow, so he benefited from that greatly, just as he took knowledge from other scholars of Diriyah such as Sheikh Sulaiman bin Abdul Wahhab, and Sheikh Hussein bin Ghannam. And he persevered in acquiring knowledge with seriousness and diligence, and that coincided with good understanding, sharp intelligence, and strong memory from him, so he excelled in the Sharia sciences generally, and realized the Arabic sciences well, and reached a great level until he became one of the greatest scholars of Najd, and one of the most knowledgeable and capable, and his answers are the biggest witness to that.

text: Ibn Qasim said: He reached a level in the rational and transmitted sciences, having a long hand in principles, branches, hadith, Arabic language, and others, rare in example in religiosity and worship, combined types of virtues and high qualities, combined the two traits of knowledge and forbearance, lineage and nobility, intellect and merit, teaching and authorship, fatwas and advice, the unique of the age in types of virtues, his gatherings are populated with knowledge, filled with jurists, his times are linked with good, and his morals are famous for intelligence, end quote. Ibn Bassam said: When he reached this great level of knowledge, he sat for teaching in the city of Diriyah, blooming with scholars and populated with students and listeners, so Allah Almighty benefited many people with his knowledge, and a large crowd benefited from him. So among his brilliant students were his son Sheikh Abdul Aziz bin Muammar - author of the book "Minhat Al-Qarib Al-Mujib in Responding to the Worshippers of the Cross" -, and the Sheikh, the Muhaddith, the Jurist, the Scholar Sulaiman bin Abdullah Al Sheikh, and the Sheikh, the Scholar, the Imam Abdul Rahman bin Hasan, and the Sheikh, the Investigating Scholar Abdullah bin Abdul Rahman Aba Butain, and Sheikh Abdul Aziz bin Hamad bin Musharraf, and Sheikh Uthman bin Abdul Jabbar bin Shabana, and Sheikh Ali bin Hasan Al-Yamani, and Sheikh Jam'an bin Nasser, and other scholars. He was also sought for questions and fatwas from parts of the Arabian Peninsula, so he answered them with edited sound answers that indicate extensive knowledge, pure jurisprudence, and long ability in

text: all Sharia sciences, so in his fatwas and treatises came benefits exceeding what was written before him by the jurists, indicating good disposal, and beautiful extraction on the words of the scholars who preceded him. So his fatwas and treatises, if collected, would make a large useful volume, but they were printed scattered with the fatwas and treatises of the scholars of Najd, end quote. And Muhammad bin Uthman Al-Qadi said: He had a prominent position, and a fame that reached the horizons, and his word had influence, and he was the preacher of his time, and his sermons had an impact on the hearts, abundant tears never leaving his cheek... And he used to preach to people after prayers in Diriyah and in Hijaz during his stay there, enjoining good and forbidding evil, and the rulers strengthening his resolve, and Allah benefited nations that cannot be counted through him, and he erased innovations that were in Hijaz, so the Sharif demolished domes that were on graves due to his valuable guidance, and he had prestige, and his speech had an impact on hearts, end quote. Sheikh Ibn Bassam - may Allah protect him - said: The notable of Hijaz, the Salafi Sheikh Muhammad bin Hussein Nasif told me, he said a trustworthy man from Al-Attiyah from the people of Jeddah told me from his father who said: We gathered in Ukasha Mosque when Hamad bin Nasser arrived with the peace treaty between Saud and Ghalib, so he ascended the pulpit and delivered an eloquent sermon revolving around the realization of monotheism and sincerity of worship, then warned against abandoning prayers, and ordered performing them in mosques, and forbade smoking tobacco, selling it and using it, just as he ordered the demolition of domes that were on graves, and ordered attendance to mosques to hear the treatises of Sheikh Muhammad bin Abdul Wahhab, so people complied with all this, so you would not see tobacco neither in use nor sale, and mosques became crowded with worshipers and domes on graves were demolished, and people started attending to hear the lesson, end quote.

text: He was trusted by the emirs, for Imam Abdul Aziz sent him in the year "1211 AH" to Sharif Ghalib, the Emir of Mecca - and the reason for this mission and what happened in it has been mentioned previously -. Had it not been for his scientific standing and firm mentality, Imam Abdul Aziz would not have chosen him and the scholars of Diriyah would not have supported him to be the great ambassador in this great task, so he began debating the scholars with their schools of thought, and responding to them from their books and the sayings of their imams. In the year "1222 AH", Imam Saud sent him as the head of judges of Mecca Al-Mukarramah, so he stayed judging, and was correct in his rulings, and remained in his position until Allah took his soul in the middle ten days of Dhu al-Hijjah in the year "1225 AH" in Mecca, and Muslims prayed over him under the honorable Kaaba, then they went out with him from the Haram to Al-Baydiyah, and Imam Saud bin Abdul Aziz came out from the palace and prayed over him with a large number and he was buried in Mecca, end quote. From Ibn Bishr as in Al-Rawdah.

text: Found at the beginning of the copies the following text (1): In the name of Allah, the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful, and in Him we seek help (2). So the debate took place in several sessions before the governor of Mecca in a great gathering of its people, and that was in the month of Rajab of the mentioned year "1211 AH" of his migration, peace and blessings be upon him. So the truth appeared and became clear, and falsehood was lowered and submitted, and the opponent admitted after the clarification. book_title: Al-Fawakeh Al-Adhab in response to those who did not rule by the Sunnah and the Book
text: Reason for writing this treatise and its description When it was the year two hundred and eleven after one thousand "1211 AH" of the migration of the Chosen One, peace and blessings be upon him, the Emir of Mecca Sharif Ghalib bin Musa'id sent to Imam Abdul Aziz bin Saud, may Allah have mercy on him, requesting him to send him some scholars of his country, to verify the essence of their call which was about to enter his city, and to debate the scholars of the Haram on issues of the branches and origin of religion. So Imam Abdul Aziz did nothing but send him some verifying scholars, who have a firm footing in debating with arguments and proofs, to unveil the truth of the call of the people of Najd, the monotheists, and to shoot with the arrows of monotheism the doubts of the polytheists, and at their head was Hamad bin Muammar, one of the prominent scholars. When they arrived at the House of Allah, the Sacred, and performed Umrah in comfort and peace, Sharif Ghalib received them with a beautiful reception, and honored them greatly. Then after that the debate was held, and the dispute and quarrel intensified - between Sheikh Hamad and the scholars of Mecca the Abundant - and crowds gathered for this exchange, and people gathered for it from the settled and the bedouin (1). So Sheikh Hamad established the argument and evidence against them, and cut off the path and way for them, and clarified to them the ugliness of what fathers
foot_note: 1. And how excellent is what Sheikh al-Islam Abu Al-Abbas Ibn Taymiyyah, may Allah have mercy on him, said in his response to Al-Bakri "p. 359": And the people of Sunnah, if they confront the people of innovation, have a share of the confrontation between believers and disbelievers, end quote.

text: and sheikhs of the generation were upon, of directing worship to other than Allah without proof or reasoning. So their necks submitted to his evidences, and their argument (1) and proof were humiliated before them, and they were certain that the truth was in what came to them. But Satan dictated to them, and adorned for them their evil deeds, so they relapsed on their heads, and said what their followers and ancestors said: {Indeed, we found our fathers upon a religion, and we are following in their footsteps} [Surah Az-Zukhruf - 23]. Sheikh Hussein bin Ghannam said in his book "Rawdat Al-Afkar wal-Afham" 2/ 202: And the description of what happened from them is that they attended at the house of the Sharif, facing the Holy House of Allah, so the first thing they opened with speaking and addressing, and agreed upon in demands, and dialogue and negotiation took place between them, and addressing regarding it and discussion, was the issue of fighting the monotheists among people, and revealing the veils of confusion from its face, so Hamad requested clarification of the argument and evidence, and the proof free from defects, and the definitive text for probability and interpretation, and suppressor of all sayings, on that method and way, so he brought them the decisive, suppressive text, for every listening ear and hearer, and brought from the authentic preponderant hadiths, and the brilliant clear evidences, what healed and sufficed, and made them on the brink of cutting the tongue and argument, and removed the darkness from its face and expelled it, so the breeze of truth blew on their spider's house and destroyed it, and tore their traces and lighthouse after it blew on them and scattered them, and stopped them on the textual evidence, so they admitted and submitted to those texts, and submission issued from them after Satan carried them on the fact that those were not written in books, nor connected in them and established, and they uttered that in the presence of the Sharif, until Hamad stopped them on what was there, and quoted from the books

text: The Khuluf (successors) (1) who say what they do not do, and do what they are not ordered. So this is the Sunnah of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, and this (2) is the way of the Companions and those who followed them in goodness. Was it reported from any of them with an authentic or hasan (4) transmission (3) that if they had a need they intended the graves and supplicated near them, and rubbed against them, let alone asking their occupants to bring benefits and remove hardships? It is known that something like this is what motivations and incentives abound to transmit, and they had among them many graves of the companions of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, in the regions, so they were plentiful. Yet none of them sought aid at a grave nor called upon it, nor sought healing by it, nor sought victory by it, nor did any of the Companions seek aid from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, after his death, nor from other prophets, nor did they intend to supplicate at the graves of the prophets, nor pray at them. If there is (5) an authentic or hasan trace regarding this, then show it to us. Rather, what is authentic from them contradicts what you went to. And when people suffered drought in the time (6) of Umar bin Al-Khattab, he sought rain through Al-Abbas and sought means through his supplication and said: "O Allah, we used to seek means to You through our Prophet so You would give us rain, and we seek means to You through the uncle of our Prophet so give us rain," and they would be given rain as (7) established in Sahih Al-Bukhari in the Book (8) of Seeking Rain from his Sahih (9).

The Almighty said: {And [He revealed] that the masjids are for Allah, so do not invoke
foot_note: 1. Sheikh al-Islam Abu Al-Abbas Ibn Taymiyyah said in his response to Al-Bakri "p. 232": Asking the dead and the absent, whether prophet or otherwise, is among the forbidden abominations by agreement of the Imams of Muslims. Allah did not order it nor His Messenger, nor did any of the Companions or those who followed them in goodness do it, nor did any of the Imams of Muslims deem it desirable. And this is among what is known by necessity from the religion of Muslims that none of them used to say: If a calamity befell him or a need presented itself to a dead person, O my master so-and-so I am in your protection or fulfill my need. And The Exalted said: {And they cannot intercede except on behalf of one whom He approves} [Al-Anbiya: 28]. And The Exalted said: {Intercession does not benefit with Him except for one whom He permits} [Saba: 23]. And in the two Sahihs from multiple paths from the Messenger of Allah, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him—who is the master of the sons of Adam and the most noble of creation to Allah—that he said: "I will come under the Throne and fall prostrate to Allah. Then He will open up for me praises that I cannot enumerate now. He will leave me as long as Allah wills to leave me, then it will be said: 'O Muhammad, raise your head. Speak, and you will be heard; intercede, and your intercession will be accepted.' He said: Then a limit will be set for me, and I will admit them into Paradise, then I will return"—and he mentioned this four times (1)—may Allah's prayers and peace be upon him and upon all the prophets. Imam Al-Bakri Al-Shafi'i, may Allah have mercy on him, said regarding the saying of the Exalted: {And warn by it those who fear that they will be gathered to their Lord - there is not for them besides Him any protector or intercessor} [Al-An'am: 51]: He negated the intercessor even though intercession occurs in the Hereafter, because since it does not occur except by His permission, it is as if it is non-existent from anyone else, and it is so. However, Allah made that to clarify ranks. The sentence of negation is a circumstantial clause (Hal) from the pronoun "gathered," and it is the place of fear, and the intent is the disobedient believers. End quote. He also said regarding the saying of the Exalted: {That Day, no intercession will benefit except [that of] one to whom the Most Merciful has given permission and has accepted his word} [Ta-Ha: 109]: This indicates that intercession is for the believers only.

book_title: Al-Fawakih al-Adhab fi al-Radd 'ala man lam Yuhakkim as-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: And Al-Hafiz Imad Ad-Din Ibn Kathir said regarding the saying of the Exalted: {Say, "Who is Lord of the heavens and earth?" Say, "Allah"} [Ar-Ra'd: 16] (1): The Exalted affirms that there is no deity but Him because they acknowledge that He (2) is the One who created the heavens and the earth, and He is their Lord and Sustainer. Yet, despite this, they have taken protectors besides Him (3) whom they worship. These polytheists only worshipped alongside Him deities which they acknowledge are created and are His servants. As they used to say in their Talbiyah: "Labbaik, You have no partner, except a partner who is Yours; You own him and what he owns." And as He informed about them in His saying: {We only worship them that they may bring us nearer to Allah in position} [Az-Zumar: 3]. So the Exalted denounced that from them since they believed that, while He, the Exalted, is such that no one intercedes with Him except by His permission, nor does intercession benefit with Him except for whom He permits. Furthermore, He (4) has sent His Messengers from the first of them to the last of them forbidding them from that and prohibiting them from worshipping anyone other than Allah, but they denied them. End quote (5). The intention is to clarify the Shirk of the polytheists whom the Messenger of Allah, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him, fought, and that they only intended, from those they worshipped, closeness to Allah and seeking their intercession with Allah. And to clarify that seeking needs from the dead and calling for their aid in hardships is of the Shirk for which Allah declared the polytheists to be disbelievers. And to clarify that intercession belongs entirely to Allah; no one has any share of the command with Him. And that there is no intercession except after Allah's permission. And that He, the Exalted, does not grant permission except for one whose speech

book_title: Al-Fawakih al-Adhab fi al-Radd 'ala man lam Yuhakkim as-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: and action He is pleased with. And that He is not pleased with anything except Tawhid. As the evidences indicating that have preceded. It is known that the highest of creation, the best of them, and the most noble of them to Allah are: The Messengers (1) and the Close Angels. Yet they are purely servants; they do not precede Him in speech, nor do they advance before Him, nor do they do anything except after His permission to them and His command. So Allah, the Glorified, permits whom He wills to intercede regarding it. Thus, true intercession belongs to Him, the Exalted, and the one who intercedes (2) with Him only intercedes by His permission and command. The intercession, the Glorified, returns to Himself, which is His will to have mercy on His servant. This is contrary to the polytheistic intercession which the polytheists and those who agreed with them affirmed, which He, the Glorified, invalidated in His Book by saying: {And fear a Day when no soul will suffice for another soul at all, nor will compensation be accepted from it, nor will intercession benefit it} The Verse [Al-Baqarah: 123]. And The Exalted said: {O you who have believed, spend from that which We have provided for you before there comes a Day in which there is no exchange and no friendship and no intercession} [Al-Baqarah: 254]. For this reason, the happiest of people with the intercession of the Master of Intercessors on the Day of Resurrection are the people of Tawhid, as the texts have explicitly stated. Al-Bukhari narrated from Abu Hurairah from the Prophet, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him, that he said: "The happiest of people with my intercession on the Day of Resurrection is he who says: 'There is no deity but Allah,' sincerely from his heart" (3).

And Imam Ahmad reported it 2/307 - 518 via the path of Mu'awiyah bin Mughith - or Mu'attib - Al-Hudhali from Abu Hurairah with a wording close to this.

book_title: Al-Fawakih al-Adhab fi al-Radd 'ala man lam Yuhakkim as-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: And from Awf bin Malik who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him, said: "A comer came to me from my Lord and gave me the choice between half of my Ummah entering (1) Paradise and intercession. I chose intercession, and it is for whoever dies not associating anything with Allah." Narrated by At-Tirmidhi and Ibn Majah (2). So the happiest of people with the intercession of the Messenger of Allah, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him, are the people of Tawhid, and those who stripped Tawhid for Allah and purified it from polytheistic attachments. They are the ones whom Allah, the Glorified, is pleased with. The Exalted said: {And they cannot intercede except on behalf of one whom He approves} [Al-Anbiya: 28]. And The Exalted said: {That Day, no intercession will benefit except [that of] one to whom the Most Merciful has given permission and has accepted his word} [Ta-Ha: 109]. So He, the Glorified, informed that on that Day, beneficial intercession will not occur except after His satisfaction with the word of the one interceded for and His permission for the intercessor regarding him. As for the polytheist, He does not approve of him, nor is He pleased with his word, so He does not permit the intercessors to intercede for him. For He, the Glorified, made it conditional upon two matters: His satisfaction with the one interceded for, and His permission for the intercessor. So unless the combination of both matters exists, intercession does not exist. And this intercession, in reality, is from Him, the Glorified, for He is the One who permitted, the One who accepted, the One who was pleased with the interceded for, and the One who guided him to do what makes him deserving of intercession.

All of them from the path of Qatadah from Abu Al-Malih from Awf bin Malik... with it, containing a story. The hadith has paths from Awf bin Malik; this is not the place to elaborate on them.

book_title: Al-Fawakih al-Adhab fi al-Radd 'ala man lam Yuhakkim as-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: For the Lord, Blessed and Exalted is He, is the One who bestows favor upon the people of sincerity, forgiving them through the supplication of one He permitted to intercede in order to honor him. Thus, the intercession negated by the Quran is that which contains Shirk. For this reason, He, the Glorified, affirmed it by His permission in places in His Book. And the Prophet, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him, clarified that it will not be except for the people of Tawhid, as preceded in the hadith of Abu Hurairah and Awf bin Malik. So the one who takes an intercessor is a polytheist; intercession will not benefit him, nor will intercession be made for him. But the one who takes the Lord alone as his God and Object of Worship, He is the One who permits, the Glorified, for the intercessor to intercede for him. The Exalted said: {Or have they taken other than Allah as intercessors? Say, "Even though they do not possess anything, nor do they reason?" Say, "To Allah belongs [the right to allow] intercession entirely..."} The Verse [Az-Zumar: 43-44]. And The Exalted said: {And they worship other than Allah that which neither harms them nor benefits them, and they say, "These are our intercessors with Allah." Say, "Do you inform Allah of something He does not know in the heavens or on the earth?" Exalted is He and high above what they associate with Him} [Yunus: 18]. So He clarified that those who take intercessors are polytheists, and that intercession is not achieved by taking them, but is achieved by His permission, the Glorified and Exalted, for the intercessor, and His satisfaction with the one interceded for, as its explanation has preceded. The intention is that the Book and the Sunnah have indicated that whoever makes the Angels, the Prophets, Ibn Abbas, Abu Talib, Al-Mahjoub "or others among the Prophets and Righteous" (1) intermediaries between himself and Allah to intercede for him with Allah due to their closeness to Allah, as is done with kings, is a disbelieving polytheist, whose wealth and blood are lawful, even if he says: I testify that there is no deity but Allah, and I testify (2) that Muhammad is the Messenger of Allah, and prays, and fasts, and claims he is a Muslim. Rather, he is among the greatest losers in deeds, whose effort is lost in worldly life, while they think that they are doing well in work.

book_title: Al-Fawakih al-Adhab fi al-Radd 'ala man lam Yuhakkim as-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: Whoever contemplates the Noble Quran will find it explicitly stating that the polytheists whom the Messenger of Allah, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him, fought, acknowledged that Allah, the Glorified, is the Creator, the Sustainer, and that the seven heavens and whoever is in them, and the seven earths and whoever is in them, are all His slaves, under His coercion and disposal, as He, the Exalted, narrated about them in Surah "Yunus," Surah "Al-Mu'minun," "Al-Ankabut," and other Surahs. And he will find it explicitly stating that the polytheists call upon the righteous, as the Exalted mentioned that (1) about them in Surah "Subhan" (Al-Isra), "Al-Ma'idah," and other Surahs. Likewise, He informed (2) about them that they worship the Angels, as He mentioned that in "Al-Furqan" (3), "Saba," and "An-Najm." And he will find it explicitly stating also (4) that the polytheists only intended, from those they worshipped, intercession and closeness to Allah, as the Exalted mentioned that about them in Surah "Yunus," "Az-Zumar," and other Surahs (5). So if it becomes clear to you that the Quran has explicitly stated these three issues, meaning: The polytheists' acknowledgment of Tawhid of Lordship (Rububiyyah); that they call upon the righteous; and that they only intended (6) from them intercession "closeness to Allah" (7). It becomes clear to you that what is done at the graves today, of asking them to bring benefits and remove hardships, is the Major Shirk for which Allah declared the polytheists to be disbelievers

text: because these polytheists are assimilators (Mushabbihah); they likened the Creator, the Exalted, to the creature (1). In the Quran and the speech of the scholars regarding the refutation of these people is what this place cannot
foot_note: 1. Sheikh ul-Islam Abu Al-Abbas [Ibn Taymiyyah], may Allah have mercy on him, said in the Refutation of Al-Bakri "p. 60-61-62" summarized: The basis of the polytheists' misguidance is that they thought intercession with Allah is like intercession with others. This is the basis of the Christians' misguidance. Whoever thinks that the customary intercession from creature to creature is effective with Allah—such as a person interceding with someone whom the interceded-to hopes for or fears, like a son, brother, helper, or peer interceding with a king, whom the king fears or hopes for, so he answers their request—for the sake of his hope or fear of them—regarding the one they intercede for with him; even if the king or prince or other dislikes intercession for the one they interceded for, he accepts their intercession out of dislike, and they intercede with him without his permission. But Allah the Exalted is the Lord of everything, its King and Creator. No one intercedes with Him except by His permission, and no one intercedes for anyone except for whom Allah permits the intercessor to intercede. If He permits the intercessor, he intercedes, even if the intercessor did not ask Him. If the intercessor asked for intercession and Allah did not permit, his intercession would not benefit, just as the intercession of Noah for his son, Abraham for his father, Lot for his people, and the Prophet's prayer for the hypocrites and his seeking forgiveness for them did not benefit. So whoever says among the extremists and ignorant that Allah has servants who, if they asked Him not to establish the Hour, He would not establish it, is a lying fabricator. For the best of creation to Him had most of their requests answered regarding what aligned with His decree and command, and some were rejected; so what is the state of those below them? And whatever He informed He would do must happen. Intercession only occurs and benefits, and the rank and status of the intercessor becomes apparent with the One interceded to, if he intercedes for whom He permitted him to intercede, and in His answering his request and accepting his intercession... etc. End of his words, may Allah have mercy on him. When Imam Ibn al-Qayyim, may Allah have mercy on him, mentioned in Al-Ighatha 1/221 the danger of comparing the Creator, the Glorified, to the creature in intercession and other matters, he said: And by this corrupt analogy, idols were worshipped, and the polytheists took intercessors and protectors besides Allah. End quote. In the words of the author, may Allah have mercy on him, will come what clarifies the error of this belief, its danger, and that it is invalid to compare the Creator, Glorified and Exalted, to kings and princes in intercession and other matters.

book_title: Al-Fawakih al-Adhab fi al-Radd 'ala man lam Yuhakkim as-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: accommodate. For the intermediaries between kings and people are of one of three types (1). Either to inform them of (2) the people's conditions regarding matters they do not perceive (3). Whoever says: Allah does not perceive (4) the conditions of the servants until some prophets or other saints and righteous people inform Him of that is a disbeliever. Rather, He, the Exalted, knows the secret and what is more hidden; nothing is hidden from Him on earth or in the heaven. Second: That the king is incapable of managing his subjects and repelling his enemies except with aides who assist him; thus, he must have aides and supporters due to his weakness and inability. But Allah, the Glorified, has no supporter nor protector out of weakness. All causes in existence, He, the Glorified, is their Lord and Creator. He is Rich (Self-Sufficient) beyond all besides Him, and all besides Him are poor (in need) of Him, unlike kings who need their supporters, who are in reality their partners. Allah, the Glorified, has no partner in Dominion; rather, there is no deity except Allah alone, having no partner; to Him belongs the Dominion and to Him belongs the Praise. For this reason, no one intercedes with Him except by His permission—no close angel nor sent prophet, let alone others. For whoever intercedes with Him without His permission is a partner to Him in achieving the objective, influencing Him by his intercession so that He does what is asked of Him. Allah the Exalted has no partner in any way whatsoever. Third: That the king does not desire benefit for his subjects (5) and benevolence towards them, except through a motivator that moves him from the outside. So if someone advises the king addresses him,

But Allah the Exalted is the Lord of everything and its Sovereign, and He is more merciful to His servants than a mother to her child (2). All causes only exist by His Will and Volition; what He wills happens, and what He does not will does not happen. And He, the Glorified, if He wills to effect benefit for the servants through one another (3), He makes this one do good to that one, or pray for him (4), or intercede for him. So He is the One who created all of that, and He is the One who created in the heart of this doer of good and supplicant the will for benevolence, supplication, and intercession. It is not permissible for there to be in existence anyone who compels Him against His will, or informs Him of what He did not know. The intercessors who intercede with Him do not intercede except by His permission, as its clarification has preceded (5), unlike needy kings. For the intercessor with them is a partner to them in dominion, and may be a supporter to them (6) assisting them in their dominion, and they intercede with kings without the kings' permission.

text: And the king accepts their intercession sometimes out of his need for them, and sometimes to reward their benevolence and compensate them, to the point that he accepts the intercession of his child and wife for that reason, for he needs the wife and child such that if his child and wife turned away from him, he would be harmed by that. He accepts the intercession of his slave because if he does not accept his intercession, he fears he will not obey him (1). And he accepts the intercession of his brother for fear that he might strive to harm him. The intercession of servants with one another is all of this genus; no one accepts another's intercession except out of desire or fear (2). But Allah the Exalted does not hope for anyone, nor fear him, nor need anyone; rather, He is the Rich (Self-Sufficient), the Glorified, beyond all besides Him, and all besides Him are poor (in need) of Him. The polytheists take intercessors of the genus of intercession they know among created beings. The Exalted said: {And they worship other than Allah that which neither harms them nor benefits them, and they say, "These are our intercessors with Allah..." up to His saying... Exalted is He and high above what they associate with Him} [Yunus: 18]. And The Exalted said: {Say, "Invoke those you have claimed [as gods] besides Him, for they do not possess the [ability for] removal of adversity from you or [for its] transfer." Those whom they invoke seek means of access to their Lord, [striving as to] which of them is nearest, and they hope for His mercy and fear His punishment} [Al-Isra: 56-57]. So He, the Glorified, informed that what is invoked besides Him does not possess the removal of adversity nor its transfer, and that they hope for His mercy, fear His punishment, and draw closer to Him. Thus, He, the Glorified, negated what they affirmed of the mediation of Angels and Prophets. In what we have mentioned is sufficiency for whomever Allah wills his guidance (3). As for him whom Allah wills his trial, there is no way for him: {He whom Allah guides is the [rightly] guided, but he whom He leaves astray - never will you find for him a protecting guide} [Al-Kahf: 17].

text: The Second Issue [Which is: Whoever says there is no deity but Allah, Muhammad is the Messenger of Allah, yet does not pray and does not pay Zakat, is he a believer?]. We say: As for the one who says there is no deity but Allah, Muhammad is the Messenger of Allah, while persisting in his Shirk, calling upon the dead and asking them to fulfill needs and relieve distress, this is a disbelieving polytheist whose wealth and blood are lawful, even if he says there is no deity but Allah, Muhammad is the Messenger of Allah, prays, fasts, and claims he is a Muslim, as its explanation has preceded. But regarding one who singles out Allah the Exalted (Tawhid) and does not associate partners with Him, but abandons prayer and withholds Zakat: If he denies the obligation, he is a disbeliever by consensus. But if he acknowledges the obligation yet abandons prayer out of laziness, scholars have differed regarding his disbelief. When scholars agree on a consensus, their consensus is a proof; they do not agree on error. But if they dispute over something, what they dispute over is referred back to Allah and the Messenger, since none of them is infallible absolutely; rather, everyone's saying is taken or rejected except for Allah and the Messenger. The Exalted said: {And if you disagree over anything, refer it to Allah and the Messenger} [An-Nisa: 59]. Scholars said referring to Allah is referring to His Book, and referring to the Messenger is referring to the Sunnah after his death. And The Exalted said: {And in anything over which you disagree - its ruling is [to be referred] to Allah} [Ash-Shura: 10]. Allah the Exalted has censured those who turn away from His Book and call to other than it during disputes, saying:
foot_note: None

book_title: Al-Fawakih al-Adhab fi al-Radd 'ala man lam Yuhakkim as-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: The Exalted said: {And when it is said to them, "Come to what Allah has revealed and to the Messenger," you see the hypocrites turning away from you in aversion} [An-Nisa: 61]. If you know this, we say: Scholars, may Allah have mercy on them, differed regarding the one who abandons prayer out of laziness without denial. Imam Abu Hanifa, Al-Shafi'i in one of his two views, and Malik held that he is not judged as a disbeliever. They argued with what Ubadah bin As-Samit narrated, saying: I heard the Messenger of Allah, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him, say: "Five prayers Allah has written upon the servants. Whoever brings them has a covenant with Allah that He will admit him to Paradise. And whoever does not bring them has no covenant with Allah; if He wills He punishes him, and if He wills He forgives him" (1).

text: Our Imam Ahmad bin Hanbal, Al-Shafi'i in one of his two views, Ishaq bin Rahwayh, Abdullah bin Al-Mubarak, Al-Nakha'i, Al-Hakam, Ayyub Al-Sakhtiyani, Abu Dawud Al-Tayalisi, and others from the senior Imams and Tabi'in held that he is a disbeliever. Ishaq bin Rahwayh cited it as a consensus; Sheikh Ahmad bin Hajar Al-Haytami mentioned this from him in Sharh Al-Arba'in. And he mentioned in the book Al-Zawajir 'an Iqtiraf Al-Kaba'ir from the majority of the Companions, may Allah be pleased with them. Imam Abu Muhammad bin Hazm said: The rest of the Companions, may Allah be pleased with them, and those after them from the Tabi'in declare the absolute abandoner of prayer a disbeliever and judge him with apostasy. text: As for the Sunnah, it is established in the two Sahihs from Ibn Umar, may Allah be pleased with them both, that the Messenger of Allah, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him, said: "I have been ordered to fight the people until they testify that there is no deity but Allah and that Muhammad is the Messenger of Allah, establish prayer, and give zakat. If they do that, they have protected their blood and wealth from me except by the right of Islam, and their reckoning is with Allah" (1). So he attached protection to the two testimonies, prayer, and zakat. The Prophet, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him, sent a letter containing: "From Muhammad the Messenger of Allah to the people of Oman. To proceed: Affirm the testimony that there is no deity but Allah and that I am the Messenger of Allah, pay Zakat, and build mosques. Otherwise, I will raid you." Extracted by Al-Tabarani, Al-Bazzar, and others; mentioned by Al-Hafiz Ibn Rajab Al-Hanbali in "Sharh Al-Arba'in" (2). Ibn Shihab narrated from Hanzalah from Ali bin Al-Ashja' that Abu Bakr Al-Siddiq sent Khalid bin Al-Walid and ordered him to fight people over five things. Whoever leaves one of them, fight him over it just as you fight over the five: The testimony that there is no deity but Allah and that Muhammad is the Messenger of Allah, establishing prayer, giving zakat, fasting Ramadan, and Hajj to the Sacred House of Allah. Sa'id bin Jubayr said: Umar bin Al-Khattab said: If people abandoned Hajj, we would fight them over leaving it just as we fight over leaving prayer and zakat.

book_title: Al-Fawakih al-Adhab fi al-Radd 'ala man lam Yuhakkim as-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: In summary, the Book and the Sunnah indicate that fighting extends to the two testimonies, prayer, and zakat, and the scholars have agreed on that. It is stated in Sharh Al-Iqna': Scholars agreed that any group refusing a (1) rite from the rites of Islam must be fought until the religion is entirely for Allah, like bandits, and even more so. End quote. As for the hadith of Abu Hurairah from the Prophet, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him: "I have been ordered to fight the people until they say 'There is no deity but Allah,' so if they say it, they have protected their blood and wealth from me except by its right," there is no confusion in this - praise be to Allah - (2) and there is no proof in it for you; rather, it is a proof against you. Had there been nothing but his saying: "Except by its right," it would have been sufficient to invalidate your view. Our scholars, may Allah have mercy on them, said: If the disbeliever says 'There is no deity but Allah,' he has initiated the protector (3) of his blood, so one must desist from him. If that is completed, protection is realized, otherwise it is nullified. And the Prophet, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him, said each hadith at a specific time. He said: "I have been ordered to fight the people until they say: There is no deity but Allah" so Muslims would know that if a warring disbeliever says it, he is desisted from and his blood and wealth become protected. Then he, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him, clarified in the other hadith that fighting extends to the two testimonies and the two acts of worship, saying: "I have been ordered to fight the people until they testify that there is no deity but Allah and that Muhammad is the Messenger of Allah, establish prayer, and give zakat." Thus, he clarified that complete protection and its perfection is only achieved through that, and so that the doubt does not occur that mere acknowledgment protects permanently, as happened to some Companions until Abu Bakr Al-Siddiq clarified it, then they agreed with him, may Allah be pleased with them.

book_title: Al-Fawakih al-Adhab fi al-Radd 'ala man lam Yuhakkim as-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: Among what clarifies the corruption of your view and the error of your understanding regarding the meaning of Abu Hurairah's hadith is that the Companions, may Allah be pleased with them, agreed on fighting those who withheld Zakat after a debate occurred between Abu Bakr and Umar, may Allah be pleased with them both. Umar argued against Abu Bakr with Abu Hurairah's hadith, so the Siddiq of the Ummah, may Allah be pleased with him, clarified that the hadith is proof for fighting those who withhold Zakat even if they testify that there is no deity but Allah and that Muhammad is the Messenger of Allah and pray. We will cite the hadith then mention what the scholars said (1) in its explanation (2) so it becomes clear to you that no scholar held your corrupt understanding, and that it is an ominous, blameworthy understanding contradicting the Book, the Sunnah, and the consensus of the Ummah. We say: It is established in the two Sahihs from Abu Hurairah who said: When the Messenger of Allah, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him, passed away and those of the Arabs who disbelieved disbelieved, Umar said to Abu Bakr: How can you fight the people when the Messenger of Allah, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him, said: "I have been ordered to fight the people until they say: There is no deity but Allah and that Muhammad is the Messenger of Allah. If they say it, they have protected their blood and wealth from me except by its right"? Abu Bakr said: I will surely fight whoever differentiates between prayer and zakat, for zakat is the right of wealth. By Allah, if they withhold from me a hobbling-rope they used to pay to the Messenger of Allah, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him, I will fight them for withholding it. Umar said: By Allah, it was nothing but that I saw Allah had expanded Abu Bakr's chest for fighting, so I knew it was the truth. This hadith was reported by Al-Bukhari in the Book of Zakat and Muslim in the Book of Faith. It is among the greatest proofs of the corruption of your view, for Al-Siddiq, may Allah be pleased with him, made mere withholding permissible for fighting, not the denial of obligation.

text: Al-Nawawi, may Allah have mercy on him, discussed this hadith in the explanation of Sahih Muslim, saying: Chapter on the Command to Fight People until they say: There is no deity but Allah, Muhammad is the Messenger of Allah, establish prayer, give zakat, and believe in all that the Prophet, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him, brought. And that whoever says that has protected his self and wealth except by its right, and his secrets are entrusted to Allah Almighty. And Fighting whoever withheld Zakat or other rights of Islam. And the Imam's concern with the rites of Islam. He cited (1) the hadith then said: Al-Khattabi said in explaining this speech good words that must be mentioned due to the benefits therein. He, may Allah have mercy on him, said: What must be presented regarding this is knowing that the people of apostasy were of two types. A type who apostatized from the religion, abandoned (2) the Millah, and returned to their disbelief; these are whom Abu Hurairah meant by his saying: "And those of the Arabs who disbelieved disbelieved." The other type differentiated between prayer and zakat; they acknowledged prayer but denied the obligation of zakat and the necessity of paying it to the Imam. Included among these who withheld Zakat (3) were those who allowed Zakat and did not withhold it, except that their leaders prevented them from that view and seized their hands in that matter, like Banu Yarbu', for they gathered their zakat and wanted to send it to Abu Bakr, but Malik bin Nuwayrah prevented them from that and distributed it among them. Regarding these, disagreement arose and doubt occurred to Umar, may Allah be pleased with him, so he reviewed Abu Bakr, may Allah be pleased with him, and debated him, arguing against him with the saying of the Prophet, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him: "I have been ordered to fight the people until they say there is no deity but Allah; whoever says there is no deity but Allah has protected his self and wealth." This was from Umar an attachment to the apparent meaning of the speech

So Abu Bakr said to him: Zakat is the right of wealth, meaning that the proposition implies protection of blood and wealth conditioned upon fulfilling its requirements, and a ruling conditioned on two things is not achieved by one while the other is absent. Then he analogized it to prayer and referred zakat to it. In his statement was proof that fighting the one who refuses prayer was a consensus among the Companions—may Allah be pleased with them—therefore he referred the disputed matter to the agreed-upon matter. When the correctness of Abu Bakr's opinion settled with them and its rightness became clear to Umar, he followed him in fighting the people. This is the meaning of his saying: "When I saw that Allah had expanded Abu Bakr's chest for fighting, I knew it was the truth," meaning the expansion of his chest by the argument he presented and the proof he established textually and indicatively. End quote. Reflect on this chapter mentioned by Al-Nawawi—may Allah have mercy on him, who is the Imam of the Shafi'is absolutely—you will find it explicit in refuting your doubt that whoever says: There is no deity but Allah Muhammad is the Messenger of Allah, his blood and wealth are not permissible even if he abandons prayer and withholds Zakat. text: Al-Khattabi pointed out that Abu Hurairah's hadith is abbreviated. Al-Nawawi, may Allah have mercy on him, said: Al-Khattabi said: It becomes clear to you that Abu Hurairah's hadith is abbreviated because Abdullah bin Umar and Anas, may Allah be pleased with them, narrated it with an addition not mentioned by Abu Hurairah. In Ibn Umar's hadith from the Messenger of Allah, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him, he said: "I have been ordered to fight the people until they testify that there is no deity but Allah and that Muhammad is the Messenger of Allah, establish prayer, and give zakat. If they do that, they have protected their blood and wealth from me except by its right." In Anas's narration: "I have been ordered to fight the people until they testify that there is no deity but Allah and that Muhammad is the Messenger of Allah, face our Qiblah, eat our slaughtered animals, and pray our prayer. If they do that, their blood and wealth are forbidden to us except by its right; they have the rights of Muslims and the obligations of Muslims." End quote. I say (1): It has been established in the third path mentioned in the Book from the narration of Abu Hurairah that the Messenger of Allah, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him, said: "I have been ordered to fight the people until they testify that there is no deity but Allah, and believe in me and what I brought. If they say that, they have protected their blood and wealth from me except by its right." In Abu Bakr's reasoning and Umar's objection, may Allah be pleased with him, is proof that they did not memorize from the Messenger of Allah, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him, what Ibn Umar, Anas, and Abu Hurairah narrated. It seems (2) these three heard this addition in their narration in another gathering. For if Umar had heard that, he would not have disagreed, nor would he have argued with the hadith, because this addition is a proof against him. And if Abu Bakr had heard this addition, he would have argued with it, and would not have argued with analogy and generality. And Allah knows best. End of Al-Nawawi's words.

text: Reflect on what Al-Khattabi mentioned, you will find it explicit in refuting your saying. Reflect on his saying: "For if Umar had heard that, he would not have disagreed, nor would he have argued with the hadith, because this addition is a proof against him." In summary, Abu Hurairah's hadith is a proof against you, not for you. Even if it contained nothing but his saying: "except by its right," it would be sufficient to invalidate your doubt, for prayer and zakat are among the greatest rights of 'La ilaha illa Allah,' rather they are the greatest of them absolutely. What also indicates the falsehood of your saying and the corruption of your understanding regarding the meaning of the hadith—meaning Abu Hurairah's hadith "I have been ordered to fight the people until they say there is no deity but Allah"—is that all the commentators and annotators did not interpret it according to this interpretation you went to. It is an authentic hadith extracted in the Sahihs. These commentators of Al-Bukhari and its annotators are around (1) forty, as Al-Qastallani noted in the introduction to the explanation of Al-Bukhari, and likewise the commentators of Muslim. Did any of them use it as evidence for abandoning the fighting (2) of one who abandons obligations? Rather, what they mentioned contradicts what you went to. Even if there were nothing but Umar's arguing with it against Abu Bakr and then his agreement with Abu Bakr on fighting the withholders of Zakat, it would be sufficient. We will mention to you the words of the commentators as an excuse and a warning. Al-Nawawi—may Allah the Exalted have mercy on him—said: His saying, peace and blessings be upon him: "I have been ordered to fight the people until they say there is no deity but Allah, so whoever says: There is no deity but Allah has protected his wealth and self from me except by its right, and his reckoning is with Allah to whom belong might and majesty." Al-Khattabi said: It is known that the intended meaning of this is the idolaters, not the People of the Book, because they say 'There is no deity but Allah' yet they are fought and the sword is not lifted from them. He said: And the meaning of "his reckoning is with Allah" is

This is the view of most scholars. Malik held that the repentance of a Zindiq (heretic) is not accepted, and this is narrated from Ahmad bin Hanbal (1). This is Al-Khattabi's speech. Al-Qadi Iyad, may Allah have mercy on him, mentioned the meaning of this and added to it and clarified it, saying: The specification of wealth and life protection for one who says 'There is no deity but Allah' is an expression (2) for responding to faith, and the intent is the polytheists of the Arabs and the idol worshippers and those who do not profess monotheism. They were the first to be invited to Islam and fought (3) over it. As for others who acknowledge Tawhid, saying 'There is no deity but Allah' is not sufficient for their protection if they say it while in their disbelief and it is part of their belief. Therefore, the other hadith came: "And that I am the Messenger of Allah, establish prayer, and give zakat." This is the speech of Al-Qadi Iyad. I say: There must be belief in what the Messenger of Allah, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him, brought, as came in the other narration of Abu Hurairah: "Until they testify that there is no deity but Allah, and believe in me and what I brought." End of Al-Nawawi's speech. text: The Third Issue which is: [As for the third issue, they said: Is building on graves permissible?]. We say: It is established in the Two Sahihs and the Sunan from the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, that he forbade building on graves and ordered demolishing it, as Muslim narrated in his Sahih where he said: Yahya bin Yahya told us, Waki' told us from Sufyan from Habib bin Abi Thabit from Abu Wa'il from Abu Al-Hayyaj Al-Asadi who said: Ali said to me: Shall I not send you on what the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, sent me on? That you do not leave an image without obliterating it, nor a raised grave without leveling it (1). He also said: Abu Bakr bin Abi Shaybah told us, he said: Hafs bin Ghiyath told us from Ibn Juraij from Abu Al-Zubayr from Jabir, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, forbade plastering the grave, building on it, and writing on it (2). He also said: Harun bin Sa'id Al-Ayli told us, he said: Wahb told us, he said Amr bin Al-Harith told me that Thumamah bin Shufayy told him, he said: We were with Fadalah bin Ubayd in the land of the Romans at Rhodes, and a companion of ours died. So Fadalah ordered regarding his grave and it was leveled, then he said: I heard the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, ordering their leveling (3).

text: Al-Nawawi, may Allah have mercy on him, said in Sharh Muslim: Al-Shafi'i, may Allah have mercy on him, said in Al-Umm: "I saw the Imams in Mecca ordering the demolition of what is built, and the demolition is supported by his saying: nor a raised grave without leveling it." Al-Adhra'i, may Allah have mercy on him, said in "Qut al-Muhtaj": The prohibition of plastering and building is established in Sahih Muslim. And in Al-Tirmidhi and others: The prohibition of writing. Judge Ibn Kajj said: It is not permissible to build domes or other things on them, and the will for them is invalid. Al-Adhra'i said: It is not far-fetched to assert prohibition in his property and others without need for one who knows the prohibition, rather it is the true analogy. The reason for building on graves is boasting and imitating tyrants and disbelievers, and prohibition is established without that. As for the invalidity of the will to build domes and other great structures, and spending much money on it, there is no doubt in its prohibition. And the wonder of all wonders is whoever obliges the heirs with that from the rulers of the age, and acts upon the will for that! End of Al-Adhra'i's speech, may Allah have mercy on him. Whoever combines the Sunnah of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, regarding graves, what he ordered, what he forbade, and what his companions were upon, and between what you are upon of your action with the grave of Abu Talib, Al-Mahjoub and others, will find one of them opposing the other, contradicting it such that they never meet. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, forbade building on graves as previously mentioned, and you build great domes on them, and what I saw in Al-Ma'lah is more than twenty domes. And the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, forbade adding to it other than its soil, and you add to it other than soil the coffin which is upon it and the cloth covering, and above that the great dome built with stones and gypsum. Abu Dawud narrated from the hadith of Jabir: That the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, forbade plastering the grave, writing on it, or adding to it.

There is no doubt that calling upon the dead and asking them to bring benefits, and remove hardships is major Shirk by which Allah declared the polytheists disbelievers as previously explained in the first issue. The Almighty said: {And [He revealed] that the masjids are for Allah, so do not invoke with Allah anyone} [Al-Jinn - 18]. And the Almighty said: {Say, "Invoke those you have claimed [as gods] besides Him, for they do not possess the [ability for] removal of adversity from you or [for its] transfer"} [Al-Isra - 56]. And the Almighty said: {And do not invoke besides Allah that which neither benefits you nor harms you, for if you did, then indeed you would be of the wrongdoers} [Yunus - 106] (1). And the Almighty said: {And those whom you invoke other than Him do not possess [as much as] the membrane of a date seed. If you invoke them, they do not hear your supplication; and if they heard, they would not respond to you. And on the Day of Resurrection they will deny your association and not...} The verse [Fatir - 13]. And the Almighty said: {And who is more astray than he who invokes besides Allah those who will not respond to him until the Day of Resurrection, and they, of their invocation, are unaware. And when the people are gathered, they will be enemies to them and be deniers of their worship} [Al-Ahqaf - 5-6]. And the Almighty said: {To Him is the supplication of truth. And those they call upon besides Him do not respond to them with a thing, except as one who stretches his hands toward water [from afar, calling it] to reach his mouth, but it will not reach it [thus]. And the supplication of the disbelievers is not but in error [i.e. futility]} [Ar-Ra'd - 14]. Al-Tirmidhi narrated from Anas that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Supplication is the marrow of worship" (2). And from Al-Nu'man bin Bashir who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Supplication is worship" then the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, recited: {And your Lord says, "Call upon Me; I will respond to you." Indeed, those who disdain My worship will enter Hell [rendered] contemptible} [Ghafir - 60]. Narrated by Ahmad, Abu Dawud and Al-Tirmidhi.

text: Al-Alqami said in Sharh Al-Jami' Al-Saghir, hadith "Supplication is the marrow of worship", our Sheikh said: It was said in Al-Nihayah: The marrow of a thing is its purest part. It was the marrow for two reasons: One is that it is compliance with Allah's command where He said: "Call upon Me; I will respond to you," so it is pure worship and its essence. The second: That if he sees success of matters from Allah Almighty, he cuts off his hope from other than Him and calls upon Him for his need alone, and this is the origin of worship. And because the purpose of worship is reward for it, and this is what is sought from supplication. And his saying: "Supplication is worship", our Sheikh said: Al-Tibi (1) said: He brought the predicate defined with Lam (Al) to indicate restriction, and that worship is nothing but supplication. Our Sheikh said: Al-Baydawi said: When he judged that supplication is the true worship that deserves to be called worship in the sense that it indicates that its doer is turning to Allah, turning away from other than Him, not hoping except in Him and not fearing except Him. And he used the verse as evidence, meaning His saying: {And your Lord says, "Call upon Me; I will respond to you"} [Ghafir - 60] for it indicates that it is a commanded matter, if the responsible person performs it, it is accepted from him inevitably, and the intended result follows it as the reward follows the condition, and the effect follows the cause, and whatever is like that is the most complete worship. End of Al-Alqami's speech, may Allah have mercy on him. Let this be the last speech on these three issues. If you agree with us that this is the truth, then that is what is sought. And if you claim that the truth is contrary to it, then answer us with knowledge from the Book and the Sunnah, for they are the judges between people in what they differed in, as the Almighty said: {And if you disagree over anything, refer it to Allah and the Messenger}. [An-Nisa - 59]. We have mentioned to you the evidences from the Book, the Sunnah, and the speech of the Imams. If you do not submit to these evidences, then mention to us their answer from the Book, the Sunnah, and the speech
